title: Easy take out but seafood dishes were a disappointment
text:
After a year eating at home, starting my annual review of Restaurants particularly Italian seafood in Myrtle Beach. So far out of 3, Capriccio's is 3rd with Gio's and Caio a close 1 and 2.

First the good points...absolutely fast and easy take out. Ready and picked up in 15 min, though that probably affected the food quality vs. the other places. The warm bread and dipping sauce that came with it and the salad were all excellent. The tirimasu was more like the traditional dish with lady fingers was as good as the other places mentioned as well.

The shrimp scampi and Linguine with clams were both huge portions so you get your money's worth, but if I go back, I'll try a red sauce dish. Very little sauce to begin with and what was there lacked flavor. The clams were ok, but the flavor of the shrimp itself was bad. Perhaps due to the speed of cooking but would not order again.

Do note, if concerned about virus exposure, you walk into a back bar area with no masks present. Staff was pretty well masked up, and you are in and out in a hurry. The restaurant area in the back was empty but don't know about the ventilation.

title: Great first meal from this relatively new restaurant
text: After taking a year off from my frequent Myrtle Beach Restaurant reviews after a harrowing escape from South America a year ago, we ventured out for our second restaurant meal in a year. With our old favorite now closed, we figured we would try something new. We were not disappointed. The flavors of the seafood pasta dishes were a little different than what you get at other places. Lots of garlic, but roasted vs sauteed. The shrimp and scallops themselves had much better flavor than our recent meal at Ciao. The salad was good, and the tiramisu was huge. It was a take out order that was ready just as we arrived per their estimated time. Would have liked Garlic bread with it like we got a Ciao, but we didn't ask for it either. Service at the door and in ordering was excellent, and the inside of the restaurant looks great and patrons were well spaced out. Several additional items on the menu that we can't wait to check out. Look for future reviews as we cycle through our pre-virus Italian favorites, but for now, I'd give Gio's my #1 pick with Ciao in 2nd place. Forgot to add one thing...though maybe a $1 or 2 more expensive than other restaurants, the portion size was huge so don't let that $ fool you! Got 2 meals for the price of one!

title: Adventure Falklands was good, but whichever tour agency you use, the North Pond Pengiun Tour is worth the drive.
text: Though Adventure Falklands were an OK tour group, the review is mostly about the North Pond Penguin tour itself. A long ride from downtown Stanley, mostly on gravel roads, with 15 min of true off roading to get to the Penguins at the beach. Wonderful scenery along the way, with a short stop if interested, at a bombed out Argentine Chinook Helicopter and their "Shoe Hill" where locals leaving the island leave a pair of shoes! Beach and surrounding areas were full of GETOO Penguins as the Melagenic Penguins have migrated. Can get very close to thousands and thousands of these penguins, hear them talk, see them fight, etc. There was a stop at the farm house there for a boxed lunch with water and close encounters with several pet sheep. Per the one review, the big sheep don't like the bread, they prefer a salty snack, but the young sheep will eat anything. Watch your fingers! The only complaint we had was that our driver was not very talkative, and didnt tell us much about the island during the whole drive. However, driving 40 km on a winding gravel road requires attention!

title: The best view of the cruise ship tender lines..drink while waiting
text: You can hang out at several bars and drink/wait until the tender lines go down before hopping on. This is the closest to the pier. CASH only but will give US$ change. The Falklands IPA was great here as well, but also warm. Stick to bottle beer if you like it cold.

title: Unique but nothing special
text: Worth a quick stop to see it and the Church that is there, but don't cut your time too short and miss the War Memorial and the Maritime Museum if your time is limited. It is on the way to both of those other stops.

title: In the middle of the attractions on Ross Street
text: Our least favorite attraction on Ross street but worth a quick stop on the way to the Thatcher/War Memorials. Home of the Whalebone arches and a historical older church.

title: Great place to watch the cruise tender line!
text: Whether a local or cruise line passenger, this is a good place to watch the tender lines on cruise day. Have a pint and wait until the line goes down! CASH ONLY but take Euros or USD$ and give change in $USD. Remember the British like their beer warm. The Falklands Draft IPA was excellent, but not cold. They have cold bottles though!

title: Multiple exhibits to see, but don't miss the Argentine War section
text: Key part of the trio of stops on Ross Street. This along with the War Memorial and Thatcher Memorial will leave you with a good knowledge of the Falkland Islanders. The Museum is made up of several buildings, some showing old radios, old washing machines, etc. but the main building dedicated to the impacts of the two world wars and the Argentine war. There is a sit down movie where locals talk about how the war impacted them which is very moving. There is usually a 5 pound charge for entry but if you have your cruise id, it is free. A do not miss attraction if you like history or want to know more about the people.

title: Much like the war memorials in the US..very moving to see.
text: The Memorial is part of a trio of sites to see on Ross street. Right next to it is the Thatcher Memorial and then a block or so up towards the ship dock is the Maritime Museum. Stopping at all 3 really brings hope the impact to both the British, locals and Argentine people impacted in the Argentine war.

title: Very old church on the road near the maritime museum, etc.
text: If you like to visit old churches from the 1800's, a quick stop here on the way to or from the other attractions on Ross St. is worth it

title: Part of the don't miss trio in Stanley
text: Right next to the war memorial is the Margaret Thatcher Memorial, and right down the street is the Maritime Museum. All 3 are do not miss attractions when visiting the Falklands. Hard to believe the impact of both the world wars and the Argentine War on these small islands hundreds of miles out in the ocean. These 3 must see attractions together help to understand that. Located just down from the cruise ship terminal, take the time to walk down to see all three.

title: Horrible check in/out experience in an otherwise nice hotel
text: Hate to rate an otherwise ok hotel so low, but the horrible checkout experience drive it. If it was just one thing, no big deal, but it wasn't. It took 30 min to checkout/check in 6 people, with 3 desk clerks. To begin with, the clerks were more interested in talking to people, then checking them in. Then though there was a line at 12 00 check out time, instead of opening another station, one person went to break and their replacement took 5 min to get ready. There was a special hilton honors station with a dedicated person, but when a 2nd Honors person showed up, the other clerk gave them priority over the 4 people waiting in line for 20 min. Then an air crew came in, and they were given priority. It took 1 min to check me out once I got there. Probably could have used the tv, but they tell you not to touch a remote with the virus around. Check in was better but they had no rooms available...said they would call. Came back 3 hours later, no call, and they were handing out keys to new check ins. Really no excuse for inadequate help on one of the busiest days and times, with little concern for the time in line. Finally, they said they would email me my bill as I wasn't going to wait any longer....never got it.

title: Bargain tour with knowlegable tour guide
text: A 2 1/2 to 3 hour tour of the highlights of Buenos Aires. Hotel pick up at the Hilton with Camella as our tour guide. Nice air conditioned bus. Stopped at several places and were able to get out of the bus and walk. Bus then met us at another place. Walking distances not a real issue if you have trouble walking though. plaza de Mayo, the Cathedral there Boca, San Telmo, Recoleta Cemetery, etc. were all covered. Though you would like to spend more time at some of these places, if you only have one day or less, this is a great tour to at least know something about the city, country and its history in a short but inexpensive tour.
place: Small-Group City Tour of Buenos Aires

title: Packed place, great for people watching, interesting concept..a group of mini restaurants
text: Different than any place I have ever been to , though there are additional places like this in Miami though not as popular. Basically, there are several food stations under one roof. There is a steak island, a pasta island, a pizza island, dessert islands, sandwich islands, breakfast islands and a coffee island, all with near by places to sit. Food and coffee were excellent so probably explains the large crowds at the various stations!

title: Expensive but excellent, but make sure you go to the right one! Near Hilton so short safe walk if staying there
text: Great option if staying at the Hilton for business or before a cruise. Short 5 minute walk. Open for dinner at earlier hours than most. One watch out...there is a cheaper place called Cabana right next to it. Don't know how that place is but based on the crowds, it's not as good as Cabana Las Lilas. Bread was great though they automatically charge you for it. Nearly everything is a la carte like a Ruth Steak House. Dinner for 2 will run you $120 roughly but the steaks and even the fish were excellent.

title: Roof top bar with a view, great sunset option
text: Nice roof top bar overlooking the bay, and some of the islands west of Miami beach. Can get food there as well but minimal tables..more like a great bar. Drink prices reasonable. Can get cold up there with breezes off of the colder ocean

title: Great food at reasonable prices, rare late night happy hour
text: Flew in late from the NE and needed a place to eat at 930 pm on a week night. No wait, ordered, and did have to wait awhile for the food, but a rare 10 pm happy hour with a wide selection of draft beers helped to pass the time. The Filet steak sandwich was awesome, and the fish and chips was large, but lacking in fish and not lacking in bread so a calorie nightmare, but a good one! Some great local draft beers at at great happy hour price.

title: Best option so far in Carolina Forest
text: Though I have more places to go, Charlie Graingers so far is my go to lunch place in the area around international drive and river oaks. Cheap eats if you want a hot dog/chips or combo. The Mo Heat hot dog with pimento cheese and jalapenos was awesome, and just the plain dog was excellent as well Lots of other brisket/bbq sandwich options if you want. Coleslaw side was good also, not a lot of mayo or vinegar just right to add hot sauce on. There are coupons in the attractions guide if you want to try it out. Fast and friendly service as well. Only 2 tables but a long bar with seats that is adequate for a quick lunch.

title: Great people, a couple of tables to sit down, free internet, but just ok food.
text:
Was really hoping that the food would be outstanding since near my house, but was a little disappointed especially with the normal price. Since they have other items on the menu, I'll only comment on the hamburger and grilled chicken sandwich and fries. Both were lost in the giant roll. The roll is huge. Couldn't really taste the hamburger. The Size of the Chicken vs. the roll was a little better, but still overwhelming. Good portion of fries comes with it, fries about half the size of McDonald's to give you a comparison.

They do have hoagies, wraps and cheesesteaks. I'd recommend trying those if you go. There is a great coupon in the local attractions guide (BOGO_, so worth the price with that coupon and it gives you a chance to see for yourself if you like it or not. They also serve Breakfast.

title: Quiet Spot while waiting for a connecting flight..1 hr free with Priority Pass
text: Initially wasn't thrilled to see that the only place in CLT and PHL airports that priority pass was good for was their Minute Suites. But since 1 hr comes free, I figured both were worth a shot. Was pleasantly surprised to be able to get a nice quiet rest for an hour, charge my phone and do email on a comfortable couch, as compared to a crowded lounge. Not sure I would pay their normal hourly fee if I had to pay for it but if you are a priority pass member, it's a good deal. You can buy snacks there but best to bring in your own food from the food court. Fast free internet and good service at the front desk. You can reserve on line. As it gets more well known, reserving might be worth it.

title: Quiet Oasis in the airport near the D/E connector..more of a short term room vs hotel
text: If you have a priority club pass, you'll see that the minute suites is the only option in Charlotte air port. Normally I would prefer an airline club, but on my trip to/from Europe, the options were minute suites in Philadelphia and Charlotte so I checked them both out. It's a small room with a coach you can lay down on, a tv, clock and free internet. It's quiet, and dark if you want to turn the lights out. You can buy food nearby and take it in for you. A great place to unwind from the crowds. It's not cheap at $40 per hour but you get a free hour with Priority Club.

title: Good Option for dinner before a Carolina Opry show or concert
text: With many places closed on Sunday in the off season, there's one place that you can almost bet on being able to come in for dinner around 515 and be out in time to catch the 7 pm show. Just let your server know and order right away. We even had time for dessert and coffee! I have reviewed this Bonefish frequently before with mixed results, and have dropped the rating from 4 to 3. Have had issues with the house salads before and last night was the same. Their Manager came by and when I mentioned it to him, he checked on it an addressed it and let us know which was encouraging that it will be corrected. Broccolli was also way over cooked. None of these are a big deal, but you go to Bonefish for predictable great food, and that has not been the case recently. I'll be going back is a week after another concert so hope to see things a little better or may have to switch to Carrabbas!

title: Quiet Spot while waiting for a connecting flight
text: Something new in the rejuvinated Charlotte Airport. There is a small place in the D/E connector where you can get a small private room with a couch, tv, internet by the hour. If you have Priority Club, it is the only option you get for free in Charlotte. You can take food in and relax. We found it to be great after a long flight from Europe.

title: If your time is limited...Pick Florence over Pisa
text: OK...is Pisa worth a stop? YES. Is a half day tour of Pisa combined with a half day tour of Florence worth it? MAYBE. If you just want to check things off your bucket list but only have a day to do both, then ok, but you will leave with regrets. The half day in Pisa isn't enough if you want to visit the other 2 churches there which I highly recommend. Pisa is more like a tourist trap with thousands of people taking the ridiculous selfies, but again, if that's your thing, you won't be disappointed. Best to spend the whole day here, then a day in Florence if you can. The half day in Florence left us starving for more. So much more to see and do then in Pisa. Your best bet would be to take a tour that only spends less than an hour in Pisa and rushes you to Florence if a day is all you have!

title: Another magnificent must see sight in the heart of Florence
text: Just when you think you have seen it all in Florence, you reach the Battistero Just the doors (gates of paradise) are a must see. Golden doors with intricate art forms telling a story. So amazing that it's hard to push through the crowds to see it!

title: Stunning
text: The entire block where the Cattedrate is takes your breath away. When you walk into the square and see the stunning buildings, domes, etc. your realize what it might have been like hundreds of years ago. SO MUCH different then in the US.
place: Duomo - Cattedrale di Santa Maria del Fiore

title: Takes your breath away!
text: The totality of the architecture in this city block takes your breath away. Though a guided tour is great tknow what you are looking at, you need at a minimum 2 days to capture everything . The Piazza del Duomo is a must see site.

title: You need a week to see all that Florence has to offer!
text: So many things to see too little time. Know more for its view then anything else, this is a great place to start or end your tour of Florence to capture most of the city. Good for pictures, and great for sunsets

title: So many things to do in Florence...Ponte Vecchio is a quick stop but worth it
text: When you look at all the buildings, etc more then 600 years old it makes you realize that we aren't that much smarter than people back then, just have more tools to use. This bridge to still be standing over 600 years when many of our own bridges fail after 30 years is a great example of the engineering done back then. It's a work of engineering, a work of art, and a site not to miss, plus surrounded by other things to see and do.

title: Good choice for dinner, large menu, best "rolls" on Myrtle Beach!
text:
Been a year since my last visit, but glad I came back. The menu is extremely varied from steak to seafood to italian so can't rate it as a specific type of restaurant but there is something for everyone. This is my 3rd rating of the new year and would say it is tied for first for these 3, and probably tied for 3rd if I add in last year's reviews. The other 5 people in my party would agree that it would be worth coming back! Specific comments:

Service: Waiter was awesome, food took a little long to come out
Food Portion: Pasta plates and shrimp dinner were huge...enough for 2 meals
Prices: Wine prices by the glass at $6 are lower than most and were large pours!
Food Quality: AWESOME, especially the strawberry rolls. Salad and dressing were also outstanding. Dinners were ok, slightly above average.
Atmosphere: OK, quiet enough to be able to talk. On a pond so nice view when light out.

Looking forward to a future visit. Note, there is a $10 coupon in the attractions guide

title: Best to do it with a tour guide, but impressive anyway you go. Lots of Walking, curbs.
text:
Before I say how incredible it is...for those planning on going, expect a lot of walking on uneven surfaces, high curbs, steps, etc. We saw two people fall during our tour. Depending on your situation, you'll want to spend at least 3 hours at the site for refreshments so grab a water bottle before you enter.

This is a must see if visiting Naples. If on a cruise, it's about a 35 min bus ride. You'll be able to see everything with a good tour guide, but it will be fast paced. A lot of people believe that it was inundated with lava vs ash and hot gas and are astonished to see this very well preserved and excavated intact city. The city square is amazing. Plus in the background is the "bad boy" volcano that created the carnage and you have to wonder will it happen again. Outside of the park there are places to get souveniers and drinks. Some of the stores offer free tastes of Lemoncello and other local alcoholic liquors. Try the Lemoncello Creme for something you won't find else ware! If on a cruise, one annoying thing about the cruise port is that even though you could walk right up to your ship, you have to go inside a building, up stairs, pass by shops, then go back down to access your cruise ship. Plan 5-10 extra minutes to do this. We were late getting on the ship.

title: Stunning old Basilica in the heart of the city
text: Basilica that dates back to the 13th/14th century filled with beautiful art work. Free to enter but small fee to take pictures which is well worth doin

title: Amazingly rebuilt room giving you a insite in to early medicine
text: Highly recommended that you have a tour guide when you visit to get the whole historical story from its use in teaching, to war time devastation, and the storeis behind the beautiful art

title: R rated fountain in the center of the Piazza
text: Beautiful statue in great condition. Great for taking pictures. R rated due to the naked figures with water coming out of breasts, etc. A historical art work as seen throughout Europe, but young kids may have some questions! It's also a great landmark if with a tour or group. Great place to split up and them meet.

title: The Heart of Bolonga with lots of things to see, fountains, basilica, University, etc
text: Busy square in the center of the city. Lots of things to do from the historical Anatomical Theatre at the University of Bologna,the Basilica di San Petronio, to the Fontana del Nettuno. Lots of shops, high end stores, and even a McDonalds! Great for people watching and dog watching. Around the square are some of the historical watch towers as well. Worth a day trip especially if in Venice when it is flooding!

title: If looking at Cruise Tours, get one that does Old Town and DO NOT do an Island tour
text: Spent a day in Corfu, and made the mistake of taking the Island Tour by bus instead of other options. Spent the whole day on the road on narrow streets and though beautiful, didn't see anything worthwhile. Spent a short time in old town by the fortress, and driving through, and it was clear that this would have been a much more enjoyable excursion. Shops, old architecture, water front, great for walking around, etc. Have to say though that from a cruise ship island visit perspective, this was the least favorite stop on the whole cruise and would go to Kotor or Croatia or Sicily vs Corfu if you had the choice.

title: Starts the year as my #3 Italian.
text:
Every year I try to hit the 5 or 6 main Italian Restaurants that I know in Myrtle Beach and then try one or two new ones. This was my first visit to Ramando's. My group's overall feeling was so so. I had the Neptune Platter and thought it was excellent. Others thought the sauces were not that flavorful on the scampi, etc.

My standard rating criteria is summarized below:

Atmosphere..Nice. Roomy, Quiet, Background music. Liked that better than my top rated place
Service..also very good though hard to tell as it wasn't crowded.
House wines were good, prices at $6 per glass was good, though pours smaller than my number 2 favorite
House salad and dressing...only two dressing choices and they weren't great. 3rd out of 3
Overall dinner quality and portion size. were ok. Overall 3rd out of 3, but the Neptune Platter was right up there with my #1 favorite, and their red meat sauce was also good. Very close to #2
Dessert...I only rate the Tiramisu and I would rate it #1!
Finally, meal pricing...$2-$3 LESS then my top choices and they have a good deal with the international dining club.
Menu selection: #1 assuming they are all good. Some unique combinations that other places don't have.
Bread...so so. Was hot/warm, but the garlic was a little thick on just one side, so that didn't help the review.
Overall...worth the visit. Good on price, great on dessert, great on service and atmosphere, but just ok on food. My #1 is Luigi's. My current # 2 is Vine Bistro

title: A drive by on the way Our Lady of the Rock, but a great story
text: If you are going to our Lady of the Rock, you'll take the boat by the island. The tour guide will tell you the tale of the island, and it's cyprus trees and the couple buried on the island. Good story

title: The 3rd Leg of the Perast visit
text: After seeing Our lady of the rock and sailing by the Island of St George, make a quick stop at the Perast Museum and St Nikola Church. All 3 can be done in 2 hours, 2 1/2 at the most and are worth it if you are in Perast. Lots of historical and very old art, artifacts, and architecture.

title: Combine with Our Lady of the Rock
text: Just a very short walk from where you take the boat to Our Lady of the Rock is another wonderful old church with great art, etc. Worth a 20 min walk through either before or after your boat tour.

title: Worth it if you have the time...good combination with Old town Kotar for a cruise tour
text: Historical with a great history, the two islands off of Perast are worth seeing with an actual stop at Our Lady of the Rock. There is a small church on the artificial island that was built many many years ago. The art, decorations and mini museum pieces give you another perspective of European history along with great views of the local hills and mountains. It's a short boat ride over and back. You want a guided tour to get the full history and background. If your time is limited, a tour of old town would be my priority but between the drive, boat ride and tour, and return, it is only about 2 hours.

title: Highlight of our Adiratic cruise
text: A wonderful stop. 5 minutes after leaving your cruise ship, you go back in time 500 years or more. Worth a guided tour to hear the history including why Kotor and many other Adriatic stops have so many Cats! It has to do with witches, rats and the plague! Bring some cat treats if you want to make some 4 legged friends! Lots of shops, restaurants, bars, etc. Can easily spend 2-4 hours here.

title: Main entrance to the walled city by the cruise port
text: Best place to go into the city. On occasion during heavy rain, wind and waves it can be flooded and they put up elevated walkways to enter. Most of the rest of the city will not be flooded Easy landmark to remember the path to and from your cruise ship. Traffic outside can be busy so something to watch out for.

title: Cat lovers rejoice!
text: Awesome selection of unique cat ceramics (and some dog) that you cannot find in any other country. You will regret not buying at least one or two once you leave. Your friends at home will love them also!

title: Beautiful Old Church...with a great gift stand run by the church
text: A don't miss stop in the old city. Beautiful old church with a large gift stand at the entrance run by the church. You can find things here that you cannot find anywhere else in the city.

title: Part of the old city, don't miss it!
text: Regardless of your religion, there are fantastic old churches it seems where ever you go. This cathedral and the Lady of the Rock are worth taking time to visit. There is also a nice gift stand run by the church at t he entrance.

title: Right up there with Norway, Chile for the views
text: If coming by cruise ship, you come in about 25 min inland from the sea...you pass through a narrow bay/river with tall mountains on either side. If your passage is during the day light, don't miss it!

title: Like going back in time....historically old city with modern shops and restaurants
text: One of the better cruise ports on the Med. The walled city is the highlight but my other reviews cover some great places to go just a few miles from the city, AND if you arrive by cruise during the day or leave in daylight, the passage is fantastic with close in Mountains on either side. Give yourself at least 2 hours to walk the walled city once, then hit the shops, restaurants next. Like many places in the med, there are cats everywhere so bring some cat snacks with you! They have awesome Cat ceramic statues that go on a shelf or fireplace mantle that are really unique. One other aspect of this being a cruise port...it's a very short walk to the walled city from the ship...5 min. max.

title: One of the top stops on our cruise
text: It's like going back in time when you walk into the walled city. It's also a sad reminder of the state of the world still after all of the centuries when the city was started that it was severely damaged not that long ago in the Balkan Wars. Reconstruction is still going on. Take the time to see the monastery, walk the water front, and check out the stores. This was a key part of the Game of Thrones sets! Take some cat treats to feed the friendly cats in the city also!

title: Nice stop on a cruise tour
text: Family winery where they sit you down on tables, and allow you to taste PLENTY of wine at your table, 2-3 different kinds, fruit, snacks, etc. as they explain their history, the wine making process, etc. If you like wine, and lots of it, it's a great stop! Not sure how you do it outside of a scheduled tour though

title: Great cajun chicken sandwich, good size, little pricey though.
text: If you never have been to a fuddruckers, here's what you need to know. You enter the place and go to the first station to order your food, and a soft drink. If you want a shake or beer, it looks like you need to go to either the shake station or beer station just down from the food station. You then pick a seat and they fairly fast bring your food to you. The sandwich comes bare...they have a station with lettuce, tomatoes, jalapenos, pico de gallo, etc that you then add on your self. The cajun chicken sandwich was juicy, good size, well seasoned on a nice role. The sandwich was $7 and the drink was $2.25. Food was ready in about 6 minutes. Nice atmosphere, friendly service. When you are done, you just leave you plate on the table. Nice location not far from the ocean or the convention center.

title: My # 1 for value, My # 1 for service, and my #2 for food for Italian Seafood in MB
text: Perfect place to have my New Year's eve dinner. As usual, service and speed to table was amazing even though the place was the busiest that I've seen it all year. For a table of 2, we were seated, served, and finished dinner and out the door in an hour. That's why I highly recommend Vine for Pre-show/Pre-Concert dinners at either the Alabama T. or Carolina Opry. Dinner prices are comparable to other places except house wine at $4 with a generous pour can't be beaten. There are plenty of options for discounted meals from the Ritz Book, Restaurant.com, the IDC book and now Vine has their own $10 off text club. When you add those discounts, it truly is the value place to go. Their fresh bread, salads and desserts are excellent. Entrees are good as well, equal to almost anywhere else, it's just one special at another Italian place just down the street that keeps Vine from being tops for my food quality as well. Their sauces for the pasta's etc are just not quite as good as my #1 place. So all in all, I end 2019 with Vine being tied with Luigi's all things considered as my preferred place to go. I'll be trying out some additional Italian places in the months ahead as I start a new year of reviews.

title: Good food, OK prices, large beer selection
text: One of the better seafood places I've been to in the Myrtle Beach/Murrels inlet area. Reservations recommended though on a Friday night,the 630 to 730 pm window seemed to be pretty good to get a table. Nice fresh rolls, affordable good side salad, reasonably priced entrees, drinks maybe $1-$2 higher than other affordable places, and some great desserts. Service was excellent and acceptably fast. For locals, there are TWO great options for you in 2020 to save $ during certain times of the year. Both the Ritz Book and the International Dining Club have great BOGO deals. Can pay for either book after just two great meals at the Hot Fish Club!

title: Great lunch on the way to Mt Etna
text: Though it was a cruise tour lunch stop, the food was excellent. It is part of a resort, so my assumption is that it is open to the public as well. The meal was one of the best land meals we had on our whole trip. Multiple courses, wine, dessert, and expresso at the end. Though the place was full, service was fast, time between courses short, and each item was outstanding.

title: Nice location, by the water, and lots of cats! Outdoor and indoor seating
text: Though open to the public all the time, if there is a cruise ship in, good bet that it will be packed with people for lunch as it is a "cruise ship tour lunch stop". Basic food was ok. As we were with a tour, it was a fixed menu. Service was fast considering the number of people there. Nice view of the harbor, and there is a really old church next store that may/may not be open, but if it is, it's worth a stop. Like anywhere in Greece, there are lots of cats around. They won't bother you unless you decide to feed them steak!

title: Still my #1 for food in Myrtle Beach
text:
Looks like baring a late surprise, Luigi's will once again come in as my #1 place to eat in MYR for 2019. Bread, Salad, Entree's, Dessert, are all # 1 or # 2 overall in my many reviews. Wine price, glass size and overall atmosphere are #2 or #3 overall though they do have my favorite wind Lambrusco, but I struggle to pay for one glass for what I can buy 2 bottles for! Their "special" which I think is on there every single day, the seafood trio in a lobster sauce on risotto is definitely my overall top entree for the year!
"

title: One of several old buildings and churches on the main town road
text: There are several "do not miss" churches and old buildings as you walk through the City. Most are free and open to the public. Taormina is basically a small town with one main street that takes about 30 min "nonstop" to walk through. The highlight is the further point away from the Central car park which is the greek / roman theatre. I'd suggest 'visually site seeing" to the theatre, spend 30 min there, then work your way back stopping a the Doumo and other churches along the way. 5-10 min is enough time at each church with 30 min minimum at the theatre. Lots of nice shops along the way...the perfume shops are MUCH cheaper than we saw anywhere else in Europe as well!

title: Don't miss it!
text: At the very end of the town, a 30 min or so walk, lies the crown jewel of Taormina. Have to buy an inexpensive ticket to walk up the hill to the Theatre but worth every penny. Because it is at the opposite end of where most tours start, do not short change yourself time wise by stopping in all of the neat shops along the way. Best thing to do is to get to the theatre, spend 30 min or so there, then work your way back. Don't miss the many ancient churches as well.

title: Taomina City by itself is great, but the theater is amazing plus the view is worth the ticket
text: The town of Taormina if full of interesting shops, ancient churches, castles, etc. At the end of the town though is the crown jewel of the ancient greek/roman Theater. In expensive ticket to walk up the hill to the Theater is worth every penny. In better shape than most in Europe, and still occasionally in use! Being at the top of a hill, you can see most of this side of the island, and have a great view of Mt Edna. Throw in a little imagination and you can picture the greeks and romans sitting in the stands watching a play!

title: Worth the drive but dress for it!
text: Great tour opportunity to get to the 6000 ft mark of Mt Etna. Pass through old and newer lava flows, get to see a "cold crater" and if lucky, get to see mini eruptions from the summit itself. Seems to be safe as well. Most tours will take you to the staging point on top for an hour or so. Was 68 when we left the base, and 29 deg up top with a windchill of 22 deg F in November and snow covered. Some tours/options allow you to take a cable car closer to the summit. Nice shop/food place at the 6000 fr level for quality items to bring home, not just junk.
